div.head: To the Right Honorable, GEORGE Earle of Kildare, Baron of Ophalie, and Primier Earle of the Kingdome of Ireland.
div.p:
My Lord, IT was my happinesse being a stranger in this kingdome, to kisse your Lordships hands, to which your noblenesse, and my owne ambition encourag'd me, nor was it without justice to your name, to tender the first fruits of my observance to your Lordship, whom this Island acknowledgeth her first native Ornament and top branch of Honour. Be pleased now my most honorable Lord, since my Affaires in England hasten my departure, and prevent my personall atten- dance
The Epistle Dedicatory dance, that something of me may be honourd to waite upon you in my absence, this Poeme; tis new, and never yet personated, but expected with the first, when the English Stage shall bee recovered from her long silence, and her now languishing scene changed into a welcome returne of wits and men; into a welcome returne of wits and men; And when by the favour of the winds and Sea, I salute my Country againe, I shall report a story of the Irish honour, and hold my selfe not meanely fortunate to have beene written and receiv'd
div.salute: The humblest of your Lordships servants.

div.head: To my Ingenious Friend, James Shirley, upon his Royall Master.
div.l: As a rich gemme enchac'd in gold affords
More radiant lustre to the gazers eye
Inprison'd so, within it selfe it hoords
Up all the beamy treasures of the skie,
Beames loose reflex on bodies d[*]aphane
But cast on solids they rebound againe.
So would thy lines my Friend in paper pent
Contract the whole applauses of the age,
But should they a neglected ornament
Be soly made the study of the Stage,
They might like water in the Sunshine set
Retaine his image, not impart his heate.
Then Print thy Poem Shirley, 'twere a fault
To dungoin this instructive peece of thine,
Had the Sunnes Shpeare beene made a thicke rib'd vault,
We had receiv'd no influence from his shine;
Thou shouldst die traitour to succecding times,
And thy best vertues prove but splendid crimes.

div.head: On Mr. James Shirley's Royall Master.
div.l: Such curious eyes as in a Poeme looke
For the most part, doe finde the printed booke
With verses frontispic’d, to shew their wit
In praise of the authors which occasions it,
And I have seene some peeces, that have stood
In neede of witnesses to prove them good.
This Poets skill is here so clearely showne
In offering light to his they dimme their owne,
For all that with unsquinted eyes shall see
This well limb’d peece of polish’d poesie,
In justice to themselves must needes confesse
Friends cannot adde, nor envie make it lesse.

div.head: Upon Mr. James Shirley his Comedy, cal'd The Royall Master.
div.l: WHen Spencer reign'd sole Prince of Poets here,
As by his Fairy Queene doth well appeare
There was not one so blind, so bold a Bard,
So ignorantly proud or foolish-hard
To encounter his sweete Muse; for Phoebus vow'd
A sharp: revenge on him should be so proud;
And when my Shirley from the Albion shore
Comes laden with the Muses, all their store
Transferres to Dublin, full Parnassus brings,
And all the riches of Castalian Springs;
Shall we not welcome him with our just votes?
And shall we doo't with harsh and envious notes?
No no, Thalia, Envy shall not sit
So high above our judgement, and our wit,
As not to give just merit his due praise,
And crowne thy Poet with deserved Bayes.
Shirley stand forth, and put thy Lawrell on,
Phoebus next heire, now Ben is dead and gone,
Truly legitimate, Ireland is so just
To say, you rise the Phenix of his dust,
And since thy Royall Master won so much
On each Judicious and hath stood the touch,
Tis fit he should more then private, when
He weares two Crownes, their votes, and thy smooth penne.

div.head: On the Royall Master, to his Friend the Author
div.l: Smooth and unsullied lines, keepe on your way,
From envies joss'le free, a cleare ey'd day
Smiles on your triumph; onely thus to blame,
Too lavish is your sacrifice to fame.
Lesse of such perfume, to succeeding age,
The dead would sweeten, and embalme the Stage.
Here is a pile of incense, every line
Heapes on fresh Narde, your Muse cannot decline
To intermissions, some leave hills, by turnes
Flame, and expire his Etna ever burnes.

div.head: To my deserving Friend Mr. James Shirley on his Royall Master.
div.l: I like some petty Brooke scarse worth a name,
Must yet pay tribute to thy full-stream'd fame,
But ile not strive, (as men sometimes) to raise
An uncouth structure to thy merits praise
From others ruines, thy just minde will scorne
To owne Encomiums so basely borne.
Therefore I write, what may become my free
Acknowledgement, and fit thy modestie.
Thy Muse I honor'd, e're I knew by sight
Thy person; oft I've seene with much delight
Thy sweete composures: but this last; and new
Smooth peece (which here hath grac'd the publicke view)
Claimes more regard; I give to all the rest
Their faire desert, but ranke this with thy best.

div.head: To his much esteemed Friend Mr. James Shirley, on his Royall Master.
div.l: YOu who the readers are of the choice wit,
And have the leading voice in censuring it
Whose votes Grand-jurors are, and onely have
The well knowne power either to kill or save,
Give this a noble greeting and its due,
May Phoebus else, withdraw his beames from you.
My worthy Friend, this play 'oth publicke Stage
Hath gain'd such faire applause, as't did engage
A nation to thy Muse, where thou shalt raigne
(His darling Ben deceased) tho should'st be

div.head: To the Honour'd Author of the Royall Master.
div.l: DEare Friend I joy my love hath found the meanes
To waite upon, and vindicate thy scenes
From some few scruples of the weaker sex,
Whose nicer thoughts their female minds perplex.
(For man he sinkes if he but censure, none
Dare deprave Kings Inauguration)
Say they, what makes the King in his di[*]pose
So Icy-temperd, as he frankly throwes
Freedome on all except himselfe? contrives
The way for other men to purchase wives?
Takes joy to forward propagation,
By Nuptiall knot, yet to himselfe ties none?
Prettie poore fooles, and Virgins! how you'r kind
(Vulger like) are in apprehension blind;
Come reade, you'le see when you this peece peruse
The Royall Masters Spouse is Shirlies Muse;
Why then to him, and her, an altar raise,
Ttapers are set, flaming with equall praise
See, see, his Genius gracefully doth bend
To the just vote of every loving friend;
The elevated Circle is upheld
Betwixt the binall Cherubs palmes, beheld
By all judicious eyess; the heart, the voice
Of all ingenious doe applaud the choice
Of your great Royall Master, say, they'ue found
Two Monarkes with one glorious Laurell crowned.
div.signed: W. Smith. Smith, chiefly due to the remarkably common surname, has too not been identified. (Williams 110-111)

div.head: To his worthy Friend the Author.
div.l: ALL these thy friends subscribing to thy praise
And faire deservings, have done well, 'twill raise
Opinion in the readers, and engage
Them to peruse, what wee saw on the Stage.
If knowing ones, their judgement thus will be
The Commendation's short, the Comedy
Speakes better for it selfe, more home; but yet
My vote must goe, I say no purer wit
Did ever grace the scene, nay 'it hath in't
Expressions of so new, and rich a Mint,
That the old Poets well might wish the name
Of this new Play were added to their fame.
div.signed: John Oglebye. To not see Ogleby contribute a piece would have been surprising, as he was the founder of Dublin’s Werburgh Street Theatre and Shirley’s recruiter, and thus his involvement in the theatre’s first play is entirely expected. Scottish born, Ogleby was a dancer before travelling to Ireland as part of Lord Deputy Wentworth’s household.

div.head: To the much honoured,James Shirley upon his Royall Master.
div.l: LEt no man thinke,I hither coldly came
On purpose to commend,or to seeke fame
By this impression,that the world may lay,
What is this Jacksonthat commends the play ?
Though tis a grace,to stand as Courtiers use
To usher in the reader to thy Muse,
Yet by the way,Ile tell him I have read
The Lawes of Flaccus with a serious head,
And that according to those statutes there
(Never to be repeal*d) thy Poems are.
They discrette stile is elegantly plaine,
In Sock and Buskin,proper to each veine
Of Time, Place,Person,and that all thy wit
Is not be chance buy regularly writ ;
Nor dost thou gall the Theater, we may
Be acted every man,yet see thy Play
Invisible,so curious is thy Pen
Which can at once,would heale,and better men;
Therefore will I hereafter cease to mourne
For those great wits,commended to the Urne,
And if't be true,that transmigrations be
They are in Shirley all, for ought I see.
div.signed: John Jacson. This is most likely the 1634 parliamentary member for Carrick-on-Shannon John Jacson. Interestingly, Jacson does not seem to be as close an acquaintance to Shirley as the previous contributors, judging by his dedication, which is comparably impersonal. (Williams 113-114)

div.head: On M. James Shirley his Royall Master.
div.l: There are some men doe hold, there in a place
Cal'd Limbus Patrum, if such have the grace
To wave that Schifme, and Poetarum said
They of that faith had me a member made,
That Limbus I could have beleev'd thy braine
Where Beamont, Fletcher, Shakespeare, and a traine
Of glorious Poets in their active heate
Move in that Orbe, as in their former seate.
When thou began'st to give thy Master life,
Me thought I saw them all, with friendly strife
Each casting in his dose, Beamont his weight,
Shakespeare his mirth, and Fletcher his conceit,
With many more ingredients, with thy skill
So sweetely tempered, that the envious quill
And tongue of Critricks must both write and say,
They never yet beheld a smoother Play.

div.head: THE FIRST ACT.
div.stage: Enter King of Naples , the Duke of Florence, Montalto, Octavio, Riviero, Andrugio, Guido, Aloigio, Alexio.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Y'Are great in all that's good.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You shew the bounty
Of your opinion, my extentUnless this word be used in an unusual sense, it may be considered as an error of the press for intent. in all things
Is but to bid you welcome, you had a sister,
The envy of the Angels whilst she lived
Our Queene, now made their blest companion
Should wee exempt those faire deserts dwell in you,
So much we owe her memory.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Pray no more.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: We must not be too open, truest friend,
Thy bosome is my Sanctuary.

sp.speaker: Andrugio
sp.l: When it leaves
To be Religious for thy safety, may it
By an angry flame from heaven, be turnd to ashes.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Your nature is too soft, let not the mention
Of her that was my sister, and you Queene
Beget another sigh, she was long since blest
Cesaria is in heaven, we are met for joyes;
You were not framed to be her Monument,
Sleepe let her ashes in the urne, conteines 'em.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I ha done.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Your sister.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Is all the treasure
Is left me sir, but cannot be too rich
For your acceptance.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: All my wealth is summ'd
When shee does smile upon me, and her Character
In the full glory, when shee's nam'de your sister,
Are you not weary of a guest deare Madam?
Am I still welcome?

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: Sir wee are
All honour'd in your presence; and though not high
To your merit, yet your entertainement is,
As full of love, as nature can expresse
To a twin brother, more I dare presume,
You shall accuse your selfe, if you be lesse,
A Prince in Naples by free use of power,
Then your owne Florence.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Madam you must be
Lesse faire, and powerfull in tongue, if you
Expect I should be still a Prince; and yet
My ambition will be high, and glorious
Enough to be receiv'd your Graces servant;
For whom I should account my age no travell,
To have my pilgrimage rewarded with
Your faire eyes Madam, able to create
Another life and spirit in old Nature.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How does Montalto like the Duke?

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Sir, Naples cannot study an addition
Of fame, beyond what this alliance will
Deserve in future story, the excesse
Of what is good, nay excellent in him
would stocke a barren Province.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Tis our happinesse.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: But 'tis not mine, for though I thus disguise
My face, and tongue, my heart is my owne friend,
And cannot wish my ambition supplanted
By any smooth chin'd Prince alive. [Aside.] My Lords—

sp.speaker: Andrugio
sp.l: Look how they flock, and fawne upon his greatnes,
These are his creatures, by his power plac'd
So neare about the King he can heare nothing
Of his great favorite, but what their flattery
And partiall tongues convey into his eare.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Pitty so sweete a nature as the Kings
Should be abus'd by Parasites, but I may
In time dissolve these court mists, that so long
Have hung upon't, and render the Kings eyes
Free to distinguish objects, if there be
No witchcraft exorciz'd upon his senses.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady
sp.l: My Lord you are very pleasant.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Is it not
Becomming the discretion of a young
Courtier to observe times and methods, and when Madam
Are you for this march?

sp.speaker: 1 Lady
sp.l: What my Lord?

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: You wod not
Be sad at heart, to sleepe with such a bedfellow
As the Duke is?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady
sp.l: How my Lord?

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Provided
Matrimony were not farre of, yet without it
There are some Ladies, would excuse their modestie,
And meete and thinke their fate at all adventures,
If no worse man would make their husband of
The honorable order of the night-cap.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady
sp.l: When will you marry my Lord?

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: I am young,
Yet when I am ripe to grapple with a maidenhead,
The Lord Montalto the great Court Patron
Will helpe me to a wife.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady
sp.l: You are bound to his Lordship.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: And so I am Madam, if you knew all;
I have many obligations to his honour,
But there is one writ here, whose memory
Will keepe my soule awake.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Andrugio—

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: I doe not like their conference.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: 'Las he has no imployment in the state;
He waites like a dull cipher and I have
My spies upon him, if I finde him busie,
My power with the king shall soone transplant him,
Or force him like Riviero his old friend,
But of more braine and faction, to give up
His ghost abroad.

sp.speaker: Aloisio
sp.l: 'Twas just for your owne safety.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: This is an honest easy Nobleman,
Allowed to weare some Court formallity;
Walke on the tarres, picke his teeth, and stroake
Vpon a festivall some golden sentence
Out of his beard, for which the guard admire him,
And cry him up a Statesman, hee's sent off
When he is troublesome to a phlegmaticke clime
A dull Embassadour, no, that Duke Guido
Is all my feare but I have contrived something
May rectifie my fate.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How much you honour me,
But you might spare all other entertainements
And bravery of Court, they may affect
My eyes with wonder, and obliege my just
Ackowledgement, but all their glorie's met
Into one height, hold no proportion
To inflame my heart, or more expresse my welcome
Then this your free grace Madam, and those hopes
That blesse my imagination from your favour.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: I am but what my brothers love, and vertue
Will make me, but there's nothing that can move
With his consent, I shannot fl[*]e to obey.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: I had rather feede upon his heart,
You promis'd Sir the Duke to hunt this morning.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I had forgot, will you pleas'd to try
The pleasures of a Forrest.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ile attend.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Theodosia, you are not for that exercise Guido.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: I wish all pleasures waite upon you;
My heart must covet your returne.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And mine,
To dwell for ever in so faire a bosome.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: To horse, the morning wasts.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Montalto, Andrugio, Octavio, and Riviero.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Some policie
Must cure this feare, my bold resolves are fixt,
I have made some attempts, and courted her,
But shee has not understood me, I must worke
By countermine and scatter into aire
His swelling hopes: Octavio—

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: My good Lord.
sp.stage: Going, but is prevented by Andrugio.

sp.speaker: Andrugio
sp.l: Sir I present this Gentleman to kiss
Your hand, hee's the Dukes secretart, a Roman
Borne, and has a great ambition
To be knowne to you for your fathers sake,
With whom he did converse in Rome, and honour,
Till death concluded their acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Sir,
Your love, and knowledge of my father will
Deserve you should be welcome to his sonne.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: He made me his companion many yeares,
No brothers were more chain'd in their affections.
He did impart much of his bosome to me.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: You knew why he left Naples?

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: He did trust me, with the cause my Lord, and every circumstance
The Kings minoritie, and Montaltoes power,
Gainst which no innocent could plead in Naples

sp.speaker: Andrugio
sp.l: Not to loud Sir, you may be heard.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Your pardon.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Why should truth
Faint at the name of greatnesse? this ColossusA person of great importance, prominence, or influence in a particular specified field or manner. Also a reference to Colossus of Rhodes. (OED 2a)
Montalto is but mortall sure, time has
Forgot to use his wings, or nature is
Unwilling I should grow to write full man,
To take revenge upon that polititian,

Our ProteanOf or relating to Proteus, like that of Proteus. Hence in extended use: adopting or existing in various shapes, variable in form; variously manifested or expressed; changing, unpredictable. (OED A1) favourite.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: It is my wonder
The King so strangely should continue this
Affection to Montalto .

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: There's some magicke init.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Dare none complaine.

sp.speaker: Andrugio
sp.l: His engines are so plac'd
None can approach the kings eare, at which hang
So many flatterers to infect it with
Montaltoes praise.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Pray give me for this boldnesse,
Hee that doth lift an Axe to strike the roote
Of any family, cannot be without
A thought to wound the branches, you were left
By computation, but an Infant when
Your fathers discontents, and faction of
This Montalto made him forsake Naples
Which added to your mothers death, the guard
And comforts of your life, were taken from you,
Having exprest this malice to your father,
A thousand wayes he might have sent you to
Another world, and taken off all feare
Of a revenge, how comes it that you live,
And visit Sir the Pallace with this freedome?

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: My Lord, Andrugios knowledge of you Sir,
Is my assurance of your faith.

sp.speaker: Andrugio
sp.l: Ile give
You reasons at some opportunity
Not to repent your confidence.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: You have
Supplied my father in your care for me
I live? why I am this great Lords favorite,
Courted, his creatures are my honours
Companion to his pleasures.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: I observ'd
Some gestures very loving to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: The King himselfe for his fake gracing me

div.l: With title of his bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Tis stange,
This newes will coole my resolution.

sp.speaker: Andrugio
sp.l: Tis truth he doth ingage him to all favours.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Tis not impossible he may be honest.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: And meane so, but my soule cannot be brib'd
So easily to prostrate To submit, present, or offer submissively or reverently to; to lay down at (also before) the feet of a person. (OED 4a) obsoletemy owne justice
And leave my fathers ashes unreveng'd
Which in my eare groane from beneath the Marble
To keepe my thoughts awake.

sp.speaker: Andrugio
sp.l: We may suspect
This is to catch applause a tricke to winne
Upon the people who did love Riviero
And mourne his fate.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: How ever I have art
To keepe my breast close, and accept his flatteries
Can complement, and with officious bend
Thanke his high favours, weare a face of mirth
And prattle with the Ladies as if all
The businesse I came into the world for,
Were but to talke and dance, and goe a feasting.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: I must presume, you want no counsell from
My Lord who loved your father, how to manage
Your selfe to best advantage of your fame
And honour, unto both I am a servant.

sp.speaker: Andrugio
sp.l: My Lord Montalto, may expect you Sir.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: It is not safe we be observ'd too much.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: My Lord you have begun a favour by
The acquaintance of this Gentleman, I will
Hope to salute him often by your meanes,
You shall not meete a heart more prompt to bid
You welcome Sir.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: You too much grace your servant,
I shall present a trouble.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Come my Lord.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Montalto's change hath staggard me already,
These favours may be hearty to Octavio,
And argument of penitence; Ile observe
And sift his close heart if it prove unfound,
He whets revenge to make the deeper wound.

div.head: ACT 1. SCENE 2.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: I would speake with your Lady Sir.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: You may.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Direct me.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: With which of my Ladies?

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: With both, or one.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I serve the daughter.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: I would speake with her.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Shee is -- I know not where.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: What Coxcombe'sA stupid or foolish person. (OED 4a) obsolete this.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Dost heare friend, I would speake with my Lady
Simphorosa.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: This way and please your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Stay preethe, what fellowe's that?

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: A servant of my Ladies.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Is he mad?

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: A little phantasticke, but very harmelesse,
And makes my Ladies merry, my young Madam
Domitilla calls him her secretary for sport;
And wonder of his good parts.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: He can neither write nor reade.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: An excellent Secretary.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: But he has beene much given too't,
To reading, till much poring night and day
Made him booke blinde, and defying spectacles;
He walkes and thinkes he is wise, and talkes upon
His old stocke.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Preethe acquaint my Lady; Exit Iacomo. 'ith meane time
Ile have more dialogue with him;
Save you Sir.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Save your selfe Sir, you are I tak't a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: And you my Ladies Secretary.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I am so.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: I heare you are an understanding Secretary.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Tis so, I am, how came you by that knowledge?

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: We have your fame at Court Sir.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Can you reade?

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: I heare you cannot.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Nor write.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Tis true.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: What make you with a booke? ha this is EuclidA mathematician of Alexandria who flourished about 300 b.c. (a) the works of Euclid, esp. the Elements. (cf. Euclid's Elements at element n. 14b) .

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Euclid, it may be so.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Why these are Mathemati[*]kes.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I have a Chest full of them in my custody,
They were my old Lords, gray when I tooke charge on 'em
But now looke spruce and young, there's something in 'em.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: What in the name of ignorance dost thou doe with 'em?

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I am excellent at turning over leaves,
By which I keepe the wormes away.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Most learnedly.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I learnt it of my Ladies Chaplaine Sir;
Men are not alwayes bound to understand
Their Library, but to omit learning,
Not now consider'd by wise men, what is
Your businesse here I pray?

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: It does concerne
Your selfe, the King has heard of your good parts.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Sir, as you love me say you saw me not,
I knew I should one time or other be
Found out for state imployments, heer's my Lady --

div.l: I must obscure my selfe.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Why how now Secretary,
Whether so fast.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: You little thinke.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: What preethe.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Nor ever would beleeve, but tis not my fault
If the King come in person, Ile not be seene.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: The King.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Few words, there's one I know him not
Is little better then a spy upon me,

div.l: If you looke not to me I am gone.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: So it seemes.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: How? dine to day with us.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Such is his royall pleasure,
He is now hunting with the Duke, whom he
Intends to make your guest too.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: My Lord I am not us'd to entertainements,
Nor is my house fit so great a presence,
To avoide a storme they might obey
Necessity, and take it for some shelter,
But in so calme a day.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Madam although
You please to undervalew what's your owne,
The King despaires not you will bid him welcome,
You have no narrow dwelling, and he knowes
Your heart is spacious like your fortunes Madam,
Princes doe honour when they come upon
Their subjects invitation, but they love
Where they invite themselves.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: My duty is
To meete that interpretation, though the newes
Come unexpected, now it will my Lord
Become me to be thrifty of the minuts,
Their persons being so neare, you will excuse
If so short summons doe expect my care
To entertaine 'em, my good Lord you have honor'd me.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Tis service I am bound to.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Pray my Lord,
In your opinion, what should moove the King
To invite himselfe our guest, and bring the Duke
Along with him, he us'd not to retire
From hunting with this ceremony.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Princes.
Are like the windes, and not to be examin'd
Where they will breath their favours.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Tis confest
An honour to us, and I hope you'le pardon
A womans curiositie.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Shall I
Deliver my opinion, while the King
In entertainement of the Duke is shewing
The pleasures and the glories of his kingdome
He cannot hide, that which his Naplesboasteth,
Her greatest ornament your beauty Madam.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: I thanke your Lordship, I may now beleeve
The court's remooving hither, yet this language
Might doe you service to some other Lady
And I release it willingly, your complements
I know my Lord are much worse for wearing.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: You rather will beleeve your selfe worth praise
Then heare it, though we call it modesty,
It growes from some thing like a womans pride,
But it becomes you Madam, I take leave,
My service to your noble Lady mother.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Mine shall attend your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: Now Domitilla, is my Lord gone?

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: I expected not
These guests to day, they'le take [*]s unprepard.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Not with our hearts to serve 'em, and their goodnes

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: I know not daughter,
But I could wish rather to enjoy our selves,
Not for the cost those thoughts are still beneath me.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: You have cause to feare I hope y'are troubled.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: It was for thee I chose their quiet life
Upon thy fathers death, and left the court,
Thou art all my care, sole heire to all my fortunes,
Which I should see unwillingly bestowed
On some gay prodigall.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: I cannot reach
Your meaning.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: By some hastie marriage.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: You would have me live a Virgin, a lesse fortune
Would serve me for a Nunne.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: Tis not my thought,
Thou art young and faire, and though I doe not
Suspect thy minde, thus farre bred up to vertue,
I would not have it tempted but reserv’de
For a most noble choise, wherein should meet
My care and thy obedience.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Y’are my mother,
And have so farre by your example taught me,
I Shall not neede the precepts of your vertue,
And let no thought of me take from your cheerefulnesse
To entertaine the King, we owe him duty,
And that charme wo’not hurt us.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: This does please me.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: It shall bestill my study.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: I must see
How they prepare, things may want method else.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: I kisse your faire hand Madam Domitilla,
The King and Duke and all the jolly hunters
With appetites as fierce as their owne hounds,
Will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: I hope they will not
Devoure us my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: But I would sit and feast and feed mine eyes
With Domitillaes beauty.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: So my Lord, here was a gentleman
You could not choose but meete him spake your dialect,
I have forgot his name, but he was some
Great Lord.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Fye what a ignorance you live in,
Not to be perfect in a great Lords name,
There are few Ladies live with us but know
The very Pages, leave this darkenesse Madam,
And shine in your owne sphere, where every starre
Hath his due adoration.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: The Court
Confine such beauty to a Countrey house,
Live among Hindes, and thicke skind fellowes that
Make faces, and will hop a furlongThe headland of a common field. (OED 4) backe
To finde the tother leg they threw away
To shew their reverence, with things that squat
When they should make a curtsey, to Court Madam,
And live not thus for shame, the second part
Of a fond Anchorite, we can distinguish
Of beauty there, and wonder without spectacles,
Write Volumes of your praise, and tell the world
How envious diamonds, cause they could not
Reach to the lusture of your eyes dissolv'd
To angry teares, the Roses droope, and gathering
Their leaves together, seeme to chide their blushes
That they must yeeld your cheeke the victory:
The Lillies when they are censur'd for comparing
With your more cleare and native purity
Want white to doe their pennance in.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: So, so,
Have you done now my young poeticke Lord.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: There will be no end Madam of your praises.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: And to no end you have spent all this breath,
Allow all this were wit, that some did thinke us
The creatures they commend (and those whom love
Hath curst into Idolatry and verse
May perhaps die soThe old copy reads “May Perhaps die so” It is impossible not to notice the feeling, humour, and poetic excellence in this little dialogue. ) wee doe know our selves
That we are no such things.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Ist possible.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: And laugh at your Chimeraes.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Y'are the wiser.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: If this be your court practise, let me dwell
With truth and plaine simplicity.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: If I
Might have my choyse, I would live with you Madam,
A neighbour to this innocence; your mother.
The King is come already.

div.stage: Enter King, Duke, Montalto, Guido, Aloisio, Alexio.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Madam though you are
So unkinde as not to see the court sometime,
The court is come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: You have
Humbled your selfe too much to doe us honour.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: Tis a blessing that
My roofe can boast so great a guest.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Her daughter
Worth your salute.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Shee is worth a world my Lord,
What is that Ladies name?

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: In this you most
Appeare a stranger, shee is the glory
Of Naples, for her person and her vertues
That dwells in this obscure place like the shrine
Of some great Saint, to which devotion
From severall parts brings daily men like pilgrimes.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Her name.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Shee is wit, beauty, chastity, and all
That can make woman lovely to mans soule,
So farre from the capacitie of ill
That vertues in all other of her Sex
Like staines, but fit of her perfection,
And when is named all goodnesse in her titlesMeaning, perhaps (for the expression is somewhat obscure) when all the titles or qualities of goodness are enumerated. ,
The ornament, nay glory of them all
Is Domitilla Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You speake her high,
And I may guesse by your description
My Lord, this Lady hath another name;
Shee is your mistresse.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Not mine, she was created for some Prince,
And can beside her vertues bring a fortune
Worth his embrace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What charmes are in her lookes.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Are you there Duke, this meeting was my project,
Things may succeede to my ambition,
If I doe noose your highnesse.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: Please your Majestie.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: All things must please here.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I follow Sir.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: This is a grace I ever must be proud of.

div.head: THE SECOND ACT.
div.stage: Enter Bombo with a book, and Iacamo.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Have they almost dined? stay, stay a little:

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: The last course is o'th table,
Why doe not you waite?

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: That were a way indeede to be discovered,
No, the King shall pardon me, he has
Not seene me yet for all his cunning.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: Whom doe you meane.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: The King, thou art ignorant
Ile tell thee after dinner, 'ith meane time
Direct a wandring bottle of wine this way
And let me alone though I appeare not in't
I may have a humour to make a Maske if they
Stay supper.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: Thou make a Maske.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I doe not say Ile write one, for I ha' not
My writing tongue, though I could once have read,
But I can give if neede be the designe,
Make worke among the Deale boards, and perhaps
Can teach 'em as good language as another
Of competent ignorance, things goe not now

By learningI had occasion to observe in the Life of Jonson how greatly these Entertainments Fell off adder he ceased to write for the court. This could not have escaped our poet. There are evidently some personal allusions in this speech, which must be shared by Inigo Jones and the court-poet of the day. , I have read 'tis but to bring
Some pretty impossibillities, for Antemaskes
A little sence and wit dispos'd with thrift,
With here and there Monsters to make 'em laugh;
For the grand businesse to have Mercury
Or Venus Dandeprat to usher in
Some of the gods that are good fellowes dancing,
Or goddesses, and now and then a song
To fill a gap, a thousand crownes perhaps
For him that made it, and theres all the wit.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: In what?

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: In getting of the money.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: You are witty signior Bombo to advance
The muse, Ile fetch a bottle that you talk'd of.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: If there be a superfluous Phesant
Twill quell my hunger for a time, I heare
Intelligence of an Oleo, if any
Such things may be recovered from the courtiers
That have beene appetites upon hunting dinners,
You shannot neede to enquire much after me.
I shall be here abouts, why thou hast wings.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: A bottle of rich wine.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Thou wert alwayes honest.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: There's asking for my Ladies Secretary.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I knew't, I am not here,
Doe they inquire already? come Ile pledge thee,
What wilt thou say if somebody be sent for to Court.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: Ile drinke some bodies health.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Th'art a good fellow, and this curtesie
Shall be remembred.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: I am cald.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Leave, leave your wicker, frien weele drinke a cup
When thou art gone, tis very excellent wine,
And now I have a stomacke like an edge toole,
But no good comes of idlenesse—tother cup,
The bottle growes light headed; how now friend?
No dish of meat appeare, nothing to shew
The Kitchin and the Wineseller are friends?
I would the Cooke were rosted honest Iacamo

div.stage: Enter Iacomo with a dish of meat, and Pietro with a flask.

sp.l: I was thinking of a brace of Cocks just as you came.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: I have retriv'd a covey of Partridge for thee.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: And a cup of Greeke wine, heeres to thee.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I understand Greeke wine, Ile lose no time.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: What's this a Booke?

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: [*] No, tis my learned trencher
sp.stage: [Lays the meat on the cover of the book.]
sp.l: Which Schollers sometimes eate, Euclid they call it,
In my opinion this wing and legge
Is worth all bodies mathematicall;
Now let's dispute in Greek, to the Kings health.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: To me, ile pledge.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: It shall goe round.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: And why doe you thinke my friend the King
Came hither with the Duke.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: To dine.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Thy braines are in thy guts, you shall heare more,
Whats this?

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: Potato Bulley.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: A cup of wine to cleare the passage. [Drinks.] So,
Here is as they say Latine: here is Greeke, and
Here is for ought I know an Hebrew roote, most learnedly
Met together.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: Helle be drunke presently.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Bottle in battle ray, present, give fire. [Drinks.] So as
You were. [Sets down the flask.] Have they good stomacks Iacamo?
How feeds the King?

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: He was very pleasant with your Lady,
But the Duke feedes upon her lookes.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: My Ladies health, my Lady little Domittillaes health.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Well said, about, about.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I am about another to our reverent Lady Simphorora,
So, so, this wine they say will make us see things double,
Here is but one Leg visible; well for this favour
Gentlemen if I be fore'd to live in court Ile make
You all in time, who can write or reade among you?

sp.speaker: Both Iacamo and Pietro
sp.l: None, none, we scorne it.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: You shall have all preferment trust to me,
And marke my steps, heere to the curteous drinker,
Now doe I finde a noble constitution in me, now
Could I leape, would thou wert any living Lady
In my way now.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: Away, the Lords are risen.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: The Lords doe rise and fall.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.l: Hees paidi.e he is quite drunk. , the King will come this way.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Every man goe his owne way, I wonnot see
The King for all this

div.l: Friend.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: This is the Ladies Secretary, pray my Lords
Be acquainted with him.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Dee heare no body say he saw me, I wonnot
Be seene yet.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Though he be made a spectacle, but leave him
'Twas a handsome entertainement o'the sudden.

sp.speaker: Alosio
sp.l: A pretty unting dinner, but did you not
Observe with what intentioni.e intensity, of observation; in the old sense of the word. the Duke
Shot eyes on Domitilla.

sp.speaker: Alexio
sp.l: And the King
Applied all his discourse to her, I know not
He has made no vow against a second marriage
But if he choose at home and looke at beauty.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Shees a very pretty talking Lady.

sp.speaker: Alexio
sp.l: Very ingenious.

sp.speaker: Alosio
sp.l: And with your favour, though she be no Court Lady,
Shee wants no confidence.

sp.speaker: Alexio
sp.l: What if the Duke be taken with her?

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Let him be taken a bed with her, tis my opinion
My Lord Montalto wonnot die for greefe o[*]t.

sp.speaker: Alosio
sp.l: They are here.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Your grace is sad, excuse
My dilligence to waite on you, I could wish
If it made no intrusion on your thoughts,
I had opportunity to expresse
What might not be unworthy of your patience.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: To me.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: The King.
This way Ladies to the Garden, let me have
The honour to attend you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Wheres the Duke.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: He tooke that way to the Garden Sir, with
The Lord Montalto.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You may remove a little;
You have no feare to trust your selfe with me.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: I cannot Sir forget you are the King,
And in a Wildernesse could have no thought
With the least prejudice upon your verture.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You have the greater innocence at home,
My intents are faire enough, and you may stand
The danger of a question, pray how old are you?

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Although it be not held a welcome complement
To our Sex, my duty bids me not dispute,
I am fifteene my mother saise.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And are
You not in love.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: I must not charge my selfe
With so much ignorance to answer, that
I understand not what it meanes, I know
The word, but never could apply the sence,
Or finde it in a passion more then ordinary.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Cupid hath lost his quiver then, he could not
Be armde, and let you seape, whose sole captivitie
Would be more glory then the conquest made
As Poets faine upon the gods.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Tis language
With which you are pleas'd to mocke your humble handmaid.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: But this assures him blinde.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: He would deserve
To lose his eyes indeede if he should aime
A shaft at me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Madam you have a heart.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: To which no other
Flame can approach, then what shall light it to
Obedience of your will and my good mothers.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Obedience to my will, what if it were
My will that you should love.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Sir, I doe love.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Love with the warme affection of a mistresse
One Ile present a servant, why that blush,
The words are not immodest, there did want
No blood upon your cheeke to make it lovely,
Or does it flow in silence to expresse
That which your virgin Language would not be
So soone held guilty of, consent.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: To what?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: To love by my direction a man
Whose worth considered shall deserve thee too,
And in the noblest way invite thy freedome
Untill the holy Priests declare, your hearts
Are knit into one blessing, theres no harme
In this.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Most royall Sir I know not, with
What words to say, you honour me, how can
One so unworthy as poore Domitilla
Be entertaind within your thoughts and care
In this high nature.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Though your mother have
Made both her person and your selfe a stranger
To Court, I have had eyes upon your vertues
Which waited on by a most ample fortune,
I have studied to advance, if you'le accept
A husband of a my choise, what say you Madam?

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: I have a mother Sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Shee shall thinke it fortunate
Bove expectation, you have not vowed your selfe
To a cold Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: When
I shall declare how pretious he is
To my owne bosome.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Royall Sir, this language
Must needes prepare a welcome, I should thinke
My heart unlike another womans, not
To obey a charme so powerfull as your praise,
But when you are considered as my King,
Duty takes off the merit of my will
And humble every thought beneath obedience.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: His name is—

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Pardon I beseech you Sir,
Conceale it yet, what gentle spirit walkes
Upon my blood, I dare not looke upon him
My hopes my feares-- [Aside.] It is enough great Sir,
That you leave one within your thought, you would
Commend to Domitilla one your love,
And pretious to your bosome, sure you blest him
With such a Character.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: It was too short.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: My heart is a false Prophet, [Aside.] Tis a fate
Too good and great for Domitilla.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Well his name shall be reserv'd, but when it opens
It selfe to your knowledge you will honour it,
And thanke me Domitilla, ith meane time
Let the opinion you have of me
Live in your trust, and make roome in your heart
To meete the husband I shall bring.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Why may not this be meant by his owne personi.e of his own person. In this sense the word perpetually occurs in our old writers. ?
More wonders have beene read in story, I
Finde thicke but amorous tremblings in my heart,
Hee's King, why not? love has done stranger things,
And can lead captive the proud heart of Kings.

div.head: ACT 2. SCENE 2.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Here none can reach our voyce be free and cleare.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: First let me kisse your hand, on which I sweare
To speake all truth, tis justice to your person,
Your merrit and my faith, next though the secret
May both concerne and benefit your knowledge,
I shall desire your pardon

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You prepare me
For wonder, if it be an act of friendship
To me, it twill become me to reward it,
Not thankes, nor pardon.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: But all truthes meet not
With charitable eares, there is a descant

div.l: That pleases not sometimes though the best art
Present it, if our sense be indispos'd
To patience and calme hearing.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Doe not doubt me.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Twill not become me so much as in thought
To enquire how long, or with what firme devotion,
You affect the Princese, Theodosia;
But Naples is more conscious, then to doubt
You bring a welcome treaty in your person,
And every voice and heart is busie with
The expectation of your marriage;
Whilst every eye bright with your flame is able
To light a Torch to Hymen, Virgins have
No other care then with what flowers sweet
As your owne name to adorne the smiling altars.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You promis'd Sir a secret.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: It will come
To fast upon your knowledge, have you never
Look'd from the prospect of your Pallace window
When some faire sky courted your eye to reade
The beauties of a day, the glorious Sunne
Enriching so the bosome of the earth
That trees and flowers appear'd but like so much
Enamell upon gold; the wanton birds
And every creature but the drudging Ante
Despising providence If this be correct, as I presume it is, it must mean neglecting, throwing away all prudential care and foresight. , and at play, and all
That world you measure with your eye, so gay
And proud, as winter were no more to shake
His Icy Lockes upon em, but the breath
Of gentle Zephire to perfume their growth,
And walke eternally upon the Springs,
When from a coast you see not comes a cloud
Creeping as overladen with a storme:
Darke as the wombe of night, and with her wings
Surprising all the glories you beheld;
Leaves not your frighted eyes a light to see
The ruines of that flattering day.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This Language
Carries both mystery and horror, pray
My Lord convey your meaning to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: I shall, I had in vaine prepard you thus else,
Pardon againe the story Theodosia,
More beautifull then the day I figur'd by her,
Is quite orecast and lookes through an Ecclipse
Upon your love shee has no heart, but what
Another is posest of.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: I know
It cannot but afflict your thoughts that all
Your expectation ripe and courted, to
The enjoying such a treasure as shee is,
Must finish in embracing of a shaddow,
Invited to a fable, not a bride
That should with joy dwell in your princely armes;
For Theodosia without sacriledge
Cannot be yours, shee is contracted.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How?
The King of Naples must not Sir ingage
Florence to such a mockery.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Tis my duty
To cleare his honour in't he has a pure
Intention to make his sister yours, her close
Though honorable love's designd without
His knowledge, and you will but waste your rage
Upon her destiny which will bury her
In her owne ruines, if your anger make
The King her enemie.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I doe not finde
My heart in any disposition
To breake at hearing of this newes, but with it
Truth to prepare roomes for another guest,
The fairer Domitilla is here sainted.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Your excellencie—

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Must not be thus affronted
Montalto, and returne with this dishonour,
Was there no cheaper person to be made
Ridiculous in Naples.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Calme your blood,
I know you must resent it, but let not
Your passion make the world beleeve you should
Dispaire to finde one apter to your bosome,
The richest beauty in the world, your birth
And fortune must deserve and I should curse
My forrward duty to your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more
I have considered better and althrough
Your love may merit thankes, yet this intelligence
Wonot concerne my faith, this cannot be Sir.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: My honour is ingaged then to convince you
Though with the hazard of my life and fortunes,
Both which must now depend upon your mercy,
Your breath shall make 'em bleed or live.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What meanes
Montalto?

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: To translate the power of all
My Starres, and make you Lord of my whole fate
Theodosias hear Sir should be mine, by free
Gift of her selfe, who has beene pleas'd to take
My vowes in the exchange, which now may boast
Some time and growth, which could not be a sinne
Against your love, with which all that can spring
From me deserves no name, nor dare I take
Boldenesse to call her mine, who am a thing
Lighter than ayre in ballance with your grace,
If you but chide the ambition, and could render,
Though I commit a rape As a count noun: an act or offence. (OED 2b) on my own life,
All that her love hath promis'd me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Tis strange.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: But she let me take freedome to be plaine ???

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is not to be reduc'd youle say/lay.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Sit, women
Love not with that safeguard upon their passion.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Shee has a wise art to dissemble then.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Tis feare it should arrive at the King knowledge.
In whose displeasure shee is lost and not
A will to mocke your grace, for whom there is
Another wound within her minde, that shee
Should weare a smiling summer in her brow
Yet frost within her heart, in which unhappily
Shee comes to neare the nature of Adamant
Hard to your grace whom shee attracts, but love
Your wisedome knowes is in the volume of
Our fate decreede, whose periods when they are
By time made knowne, greatnesse on earth, that meanes
To play the tyrant with us, may have strength
To punish not reverse.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I am confirmde
And prosper in my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: It takes.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My Lord,
You have expression act of confidence
Which I must not betray though to my losse,
It is some happinesse to know this early,
We may be expected, you shall finde me Sir
A Prince, but no usurper.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: I am your creature,
The King.

div.stage: Enter King, Simphorosa, Domitilla, Guido, Aloisio, Alexio.

sp.l: We build upon your piety
Vntill some little time amy call our loves
Out of this silence.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You understand me Madam?

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: And am honord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Her eyes beget new wonder, I shall be osberv'd.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Come, not to horse.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I shall attend, your entertainment has
Oblig'd us Madam.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: Twas not worth such guest,
But prayers and duty must supply.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Now Madam you are a great part of my care,
Depend upon me for a husband.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Ist not plaine.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Madam another guest must take his leave,
That here would choose his pallace.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: You are gratious, and but encourage more to honor you.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Ile creepe and kisse thy Altar love, allow
Them flame, and knit more charmes upon her brow.

div.head: THE THIRD ACT.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Tis thy old quarrel gainst Montalto makes
Thee incredulous, I dare beleeve he loves
Theodosia.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Tis not that I question Sir,
But that part which concernes her love to him
Sounds like a plot upon your nature, to
Secure his owne ambition.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why the Princesse
May love, as great a heart has beene made stoop.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Your grace should else in vaine court her your selfe
And late your highnesse thought shee meet your person
A faire designe of love, with all the soft
Behaviour of a Princesse.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But tis not
Impossible a Lady should dissemble.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Allow her but the honour she was borne with,
And sheel'e not staine her blood so much.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But love
Must be obeyed, and prepossession
Of hearts is a lewd thing to wrastle with,
I made it my owne case, and if I lov'd
Another Lady better then the Princesse,
As every man's not proofe against all beauty,
I thinke I should be constant too, it would
Be something to remove me.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Then the King.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He knowes not, and I have bound my selfe in honour,
Not to betray, if they be decreed
To make a marriage, a soft destiny
Attend their loves.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: There is some mystery,
But will you rest and take for granted shee
Does love Montalto , if it be a truth
Y'are in the same condition when shee
Confirmes it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Tis not good to be busie
In search of these unwelcome certainties,
There's hope while things are clouded in supsition.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: But so your jealousie may wound her honour,
Which you may cure by knowledge.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I will thinke on*t,
Meane time let this dwell in that honest silence
You have possest, there is another secret
May follow.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: You must challenge my whole bosome,
And I am confident your highnesse will
Stere all your resolutions by honour,
Which in a Prince is sacred.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir, the Lord
Montalto is comming up.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Then try your art upon him,
And informe your selfe, Ile take
My time to appeare.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: I obey
My honour'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Most noble Philberto,
Where is the Duke?

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: If youle but excuse a few minuts

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Tis
My duty to attend.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: How is it with the Princesse my good Lord?

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: The Princesse? shee is in health, why this to me,
Shee is of inward counsell with the Duke,
I must be resolute.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: I aske, because,
His grace intends a present visit to her
And was but now in mention of your Lordship
To beare him company.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: I like not that,
He knowes he may command my services.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: He will deserve your love, pray my Lord tell me
And let us be plaine breasted, you injoy
The King, as I, but with lesse stocke of merit,
The favour of his excellence, how affect you
The present state of things, wilt be a match?
There is loud expectation in the world,
And after all, my Master's fond to have it
Proceede, to these, I am of opinion
Theres no retreating now without dishonour,
Yes as I am Philiberto I much pittie
He should through any wound to your affection
Perfect his love.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: He has told you then the secret,
And not to waste more language, I collect
From what you have exprest, he does resolve
To destroy me, Montalto must be trod on.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Not so my Lord.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Yes, and my heart the ascent,
To his Hymeneall pertaining to marriage. (OED A) altar, which must be,
Made crimson with the blood of a true lover,
His will be obey'd, Theodosia shall see
To advance her, Montalto will goe smiling
To his sacrifice, and after many prayers,
That shee may live the darling of his heart,
Ile changemy acquaintance of this world to be
At peace in my owne ashes.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: You will not
Commit a violence upon your selfe?

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: I sha' not neede, the thought of her will kill me
With as much silence as I goe to sleepe,

div.l: I onely shall bleed inward, and my life
Remove it selfe like a faire apparition
That vanishes to th'eye, and with lesse noise
Then a calme Summers evening, but when I
Am dead, tis not impossible, some may
Report Theodosia was but revish'd from me;
Feare of a brothers anger, and the tricke
Of polliticke states, that marry to knit power

Not hearts, did force her to Herares armes So, this line is a quarto, with the exception of the apostrophe. Whether the poet meant to give the duke of Florence this strange name, as is more probably the case, this can be a corruption of the press, the reader must determine. ,
Whilst I, torne from the branch where I once grew,
Travell I know not whether in the aire.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: I begin
To thinke him worth some pitty.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Into what
Vaine thing would the severe apprehension
Of greefe transforme us? coward, let the Duke
Move with all amorous haste to his delight,
And glory in the hope of his faire bride,
Mine by the gift of heaven, and hearts, but all
My flowers grow dully on their stalkes, and wither;

Let her gay Paranimphs (modern spelling: paranymphs) At a wedding, a bridesmaid or best man. In this context, Montalto is referring to the bride’s ladies-in-waiting or bridesmaids (OED 1). As per Merriam Webster dictionary, in ancient Greece, a friend going with a bridegroom to fetch home the bride were called paranymphs. with rosie Chaplets A wreath for the head, usually a garland of flowers or leaves, also of gold, precious stones, etc.; a circlet, coronel (OED 1a) ,
Which will take all their colour from her blush,
Attend on Theodosia to the Temple,
While as they goe, no rude winde shall be heard,
But so much breath of heaven as gently may
Lifting their loose haire up, whisper my wrong
To every Virgins care, let them be married,
Knit hands, and plight a ceremonious faith;

Let all the triumphs waste I lament to say that all which follows of this beautiful speech is involved in hopeless error and obscurity. Much has been corrupted at the press, much lost or shuffled out of its place; and though some partial aid might be supplied, yet, in so desperate a case, it seemed more prudent to leave the whole as it stands in the old copy. , let them be wasted,
And night it selfe brib'd with a thousand formes
Of mirth and Revells, till the night grow faint
And pale with watching,
Invite to bed, yet there he shall enjoy
But Theodosiaes body, and not that
As his faire thoughts expect, perhaps the conquest
Of one whom he loved better.

sp.speaker: Riviero.
sp.l: How was that.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now shall I trust him? if my sense mistake not
Theodosia may not be a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Twas
His bold conclusion.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Where is now the honour
You talke of, durst Montalto charge her with
This staine, without his conscience to assure it.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Yes, and to me this tenders him the more
To be suspected and I am so farre
From thinking shee affects Montalto, that
I am convinc'd he loves her not; can he
Have any noble thought of Theodosia,
And can revenge in any lover be?
A reason to wound a Ladies fame, it tasts
Of ranke injustice, and some other end
Time will discover, and yet your grace is bound
To have his accusation confirm'd,
Or hant this spotted panther to his ruine,

Whose breath is onely sweete to poyson vertue As per the book Works of Ben Jonson by W. Gifford (1816), Jonson mentions the panther’s breath as ‘sweet’ in his work Volpone. Gifford mentions how this epithet is notoriously repeated, apparently referring to a popular fable, in the works of Pliny the Elder, Henry Glapthorne, and Thomas Randolph. .

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What I resolve inquire not.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: I see throw
Montaltoes soule, and have beene so long tame
In my owne sufferings; but this will make
Him ripe for punishment, Andrugio and
My sonne.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: I cannot with the wings of duty
Fly swift enough to prostrate my obedience
And welcome from a long supposed death,
My honourd father.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Then I must appeare so.

sp.speaker: Andrugio
sp.l: And let me give a sonne up to your blessing
Worthy your best prayers, and embrace, twas time
To bring you acquainted, he had else this night
Contriv'd Montaltoes tragedie at a Banquet,
For your revenge his active thoughts I could not
Counsell no longer patience.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: Thou hast but
Prevented me Octavio, I was
Weary of my concealement.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: But my joyes are wilde,
And will I feare, transport me.

sp.speaker: Riviero
sp.l: My best friend,
And my owne spirited boy, feare not Montalto;
Hee's now upon a precipice, his fate
Stoopes with the glorious burden of his pride.
Things may be worth our counsell, we shall see
This prodigie that would be held a Starre,
And did so fright us with his streaming haire,
Drop like a Comet, and be lost i'th aire.

div.head: ACT 3. SCENE 2.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Ist possible the day should be so old,
And not a visite from the Duke.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: While he
Injoyes health, I shall easily forgive
A little ceremony.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: And a lover,
Your grace must chide him, other men may have
Excuse for their neglect of time, but he
That loves deserves no pardon.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: Judge with charity
My Lord, the case may be your owne, you would
Thinke her a cruell mistresse, that should doome
Your life to exile, for not payment of
One ceremonious visite.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Not where such
Perfection were to ingage my service Madam,
Pardon the bold comparison, death were not
Enough to punish that rude thought that could
Start from your bright Idea, or converse
With praters that did not first concerne your excellence,
I would not be ambitious of a blessing
But from reflex of yours.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: You would expresse
A most officious servant to that Lady
Were honourd in your thought, but the Duke of Florence
And I shall make no such severe conditions.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: If he doe love you Madam that will teach him
Above what ceremony prescribes to honour you.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: If he doe love.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Your graces pardon; I
Speake from an honest freedome taken from
The assurance of your goodnesse, that know better
How to distinguish truth, I am not judge
Of his breast Madam.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: I suppose you are not.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: And yet being a man another way
Conclude his passions are but such as have
Beene read in humane nature.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: What inferre you
From hence my Lord?

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Nothing but that a Prince
May be no Saint in love.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: Howe's that?

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Twas in my feare I should displease.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: Your will.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Not for the Empire of the world, I shall
Repent I live with your suspition
Upon my humbl'd soule.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: Pray Sir be free
Touching the Duke, I must know all, what ist
Makes him no Saint.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Madam he is not dead,
And in his life I see no miracles.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: You talk'd of love.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: No miracles of love,
He loves as other men that have profest
Devotion to a mistresse—but

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: What? speake
I charge thee by the memory of what
Thou dost affect most.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Though it wound my selfe
Be arm'd and heare it, how I blush within me,
To tell your highnesse Florence has transplanted
His heart, and all his active thoughts are plac'd.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: On whom?

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: On Domitilla.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: I did observe 'em Madam, at her mothers house,
Where we were lately feasted after hunting,
How strangely he was taken, how his eyes
Did wanton with her face, and on her haire
Tie many golden knots, to keepe love chainde,
But these are but suspitions, he since
Confest to me in hope to winne me to
Negotiate his affaire, how at first sight
He tooke in desperate flames, and that shee rules
The intelligence of his soule; I heare the King
Hath sent for her to Court, which must give Madam
A dangerous opportunity to actuate
His ends with your dishonour, I was unwilling
To speake this knowledge of his hasty change,
But all my bonds of piety and faith
Would have beene forfeit into a long silence.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: Shall I be thus affronted.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: We see Princes,
Whom we call gods on earth, in the affaires
Of love turne men agen.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: For Domitilla.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: That's the dishonour Madam, and infects
My braine to thinke on't, and as much beneath
Your grace in all the ornaments of soule
And person as shee is in b[*]ood, if my
Impartiall thoughts may take so bold commission
To judge betweene your beauties.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: Is it possible.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: Tis too certaine Madam, I should be
A villaine to accuse the Duke unjustly,
Or bring but shaddowes of a truth, for though
He be unworthy of your love that dares
Thus valew your perfections, below
That Phantome Domitilla, let not passion
Make you to rash in managing a cause,
On which depends your fame, compared to which
Ten thousand lives added to mine were nothing,
Observe him at next visit.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: Ile study thankes Sir.

sp.speaker: Montalto
sp.l: You pay me with a blessing, if my name
But live within your memory.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: This troubles me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Are they both come to court?

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: And in those lodgings were prepar'd.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Tis well, and came they cheerefully?

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Yes Sir, but something
I nigh discerne like trouble, and by starts
In Domitilla, but they are pleas'd with their
Remove, and waite all your commands.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: So leave us;
Theodosia, what's the matter? Art not well.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: Wheres the Duke?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I thought to have met him here.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: Is Domitilla come to court?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: She is
By my command to waite on thee.

sp.speaker: Theodosia
sp.l: To rivall me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Howes that?
I meant her a wife for good Montalto,
As the reward of his just services,
He knowes it not, as he is ignorant
For whom I have prepar'd her. Rivall? Strange
I must know more of this, shee is in nature
Too apprehensive, for although in love
Suspition to men a torment be,
There is no Fiend to womens jealousie.

div.head: ACT 3. SCENE 3.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: You may doe what you will Madam, put me
Into fine clothes, and make an asse of me,
But should you wrap me in a Lyons skinne.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: You have eares that will betray what beast you are.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Pray Madam tell me in six words of sense,
What shall I doe here, Ile not see the King,
Though he have cunningly devis'd this tricke
Onely to bring me hither and betray me
To offices, make me at least an Idoll.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: An Idoll in the Countrey I have read
A thing we call a worshipfull, a right worshipfull,
Descended from the house of the factotums A person in charge of everything, a ruler. (OED 4) obsolete,

Lord of the soile, and Cocke of his owne dunghill. Bombo’s speech demonstrates his interpretation of what he has read in books pertaining to idols, which appears to have a strong connection to ruling over a land.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: You may be out of feare, you cannot reade now,
Nor set your name to a warrant.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Alls that nothing,
Ignorance every day comes into fashion,
And no meane statesmen now when they doe write
Their names, doe for their honours so contrive it,

You can hardly know a nobleman from a marke. Bombo’s meaning is better than his quibble, which is poor enough. Nothing, in fact, can be more uncouth than the attempts made by many of the nobility and gentry of the poet’s days to scrawl their names. Some of them differ in nothing from marks, but in the appearance of being elaborated with more illiterate perseverance.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: If you be an enemy to all preferment,
Your best way is to leave the world and turne
A lay Fryer

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: No I finde no such thing in my constitution,
Every man is not bound to be Religious;
Men of my bulke and bearing should not fast so,
I am not given by nature to drinke water,
Or lye without a shirt; I have cornes Madam,
And I would make lesse conscience to undoe

My Shoomaker, then walke on wodden Pantables (also known as pantofle) A slipper; a loose shoe. In early use apparently: any type of indoor shoe, also applied to outdoor overshoes or galoshes. Now archaic and historical. (OED) ,
I will indure to serve you still and dwell here,
So you conceale me from the King, tis not
That I doe owe his Majestie ill will,
I could indure him too upon condition
He would make nothing on me.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Why he shall
Make nothing on thee take my word, or if
Thou hast a minde ile pray him make thee lesse.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: No, I would be a midling Christian,

But what will you doe here you selfe The 1833 version of the play adds the word ‘love’ at the end of Bombo’s sentence, thus giving more meaning to Bombo’s dialogue. This could possibly be a printing error as otherwise the meaning of the dialogue is obscure. , youle be in.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: With whom dost thinke.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: And cast away your selfe
Upon some pageant, one whose wit must be
Beholding to anothers Wooll to keepe it warme;
One that can dance and sing and wag his feather,
An artificiall Calfe carrier;
A youth that's sowed together by his Taylour,
And taken a peeces by his Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Why how now Secretary.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I could say more.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Is this wit naturall?

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: You were best say
I got it here at Court, pray heaven I doe not
Loose what I brought, I had a holsome wit
I'th Countrey, aske the Parish and the Parson
For I kept company with those that reade
And learne wit now by the eare, if any slip from me,
As where there is a plenty some will out,
Here are so many wit catchers, a lost maidenhead
Is sooner found and set upon the shoulders
Of the right owner.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: I preethe tell me Bombo,
And tell me truth, doe not you thinke your selfe
After all this a foole?

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: A foole, your servant Madam.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Ile speake thou maist be the Kings foole.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I thanke you,
I tell you Ile not see the King, or if I did,
Yes I looke like a foole, I could be angry,
But then you'd say I were a foole indeed.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Be not so passionate.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: Wod I had beene a foole,
I would I had, for my owne sake I wish it,
I should not have beene tempted hither then,
By which I have indangered my good parts,
To State imployment, but Ile be wise enough,
He has not seene me yet nor shanot if
There be a witch in Naples, or a mist
That will be bought for money to walk the Court in,
But take your course, and I were at home agen.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I would live in the Sellar, the Wine Sellar.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Tis your humility.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: There were some fortification to be made
Against the Court invasions, countermines
Of sand and Sacke, a man might thrust himselfe
Among the bottles, and defie the world,
Be drunke, and not be cal'd out of his sleepe
To goe Embassadour.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: So, so, feare not,
Have a strong faith, and thou maist dye i'th countrey
For all this, here's my mother, let your care
Be now that none may interrupt us.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: I will doe any thing but see the King.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: With pardon Madam you seeme full of thought.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: I am studying Domitilla why the King
Should send for us to Court.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Mother you cannot
Mention the King in any act of his
That is not glorious and like himselfe;
He is the great example of a King,
But richer in his soule then state.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: But why
To us this favour, to call us from those
Cold and obscure shades of a retirement
To plant us here neare his owne beames?

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: He has some meaning in't.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: It tis yet darke to me.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: We sha'not staine his Court, his sister's but
A Lady of more distinction of birth,
Yet all that have beene Princes, came not to
Their state by a descent, the Heralds know
Some were not borne to purple and to scepters
That have beene Queenes, vertue has rais'd some,
And beauty has had many charmes to rule
The heart of Kings.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: What's all this Domitilla?
I hope you are not dreaming of a Queene,
Such wilde interpretation of the Kings
Favour to us cannot be made without
The forfeits of wits and duties which
Should teach us to containe our thoughts in their
Owne Spheare and not to point them upon objects
Above our Levell.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: I Betray my selfe,
When I sayd beauty had a power to charme
A King, it might acquit me from suspition
Of any hope to apply them so ambitiously,
Youle grant it just to love the King.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: Our duties.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: And he may where he please place his affection.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: Leave that to her, it may concerne.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: And shee
Thats mark'd for so great honour should be mad
To quarrell with her kinde fate.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: What's all this
To thee?

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: To me; why mother ist not possible
A Lady not much fairer then my selfe
May be a Queene, great Princes have eyes
Like other men, and I should sinne against
What heaven and nature have bestowed on me.
Should my fate smile to thinke my face would be
The barre to such preferment.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: Leaving this
Which is but mirth, I know since we are falne
Into discourse of love, what would you answer
To Lord Montalto if he came a wooing
And recommended by the King?

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: I would
Eene recommend him to the King agen.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: Is not his favorite worth your love, if he
Descend to be your servant.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: As a servant
He may be entertain'd, and were I Queene,
Perhaps he should be favorite to both;
And I would smile upon his services
In imitation of the King while he
Preserv'd his modest duty and his distance.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: My daughter is transported, sure you are
No Queene sweet Domitilla.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Tis a truth,
Nor is Montalto yet my favorite.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: I hope shee's not so miserable to affect
The King, by whose directions I prepare
Her for Montalto.

sp.speaker: Bombo
sp.l: A sprig of the Nobility cal'd Octavio
Desires accesse.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Admit him.

sp.speaker: Simphorosa
sp.l: I must let this passion coole and leave her.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Welcome to Court, why so, this sphere becomes you,
Or rather it takes ornament from you;
Now Domitilla shines indeede, your presence
Doth throw new beames about the Pallace Madam,
Before we look'd as we had lost our genius.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: You came not from the King with any message.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: I made this hast to tender my owne service.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: You have no other suite to me?

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Speake it.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: And Ile not wander much about, shall I
Be admitted a young lover?

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Men must not love till they be one and twenty,
They will be mad before they come to age else.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: This Law was ne're decreed i'th Parliament
of Cupid, such a Statute would undoe
Many sweet Virgins like your selfe, yet if
You'le promise to stay for me, I shall thinke it
A happy expectation, we are both

div.l: Young, we may choose each other Valentine
And couple, as we grow more ripe hereafter.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Ile aske you but one question my Lord,
What would you give to be the King of Naples?

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: I dare not thinke so ambitiously.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Tis modest, what if I cannot love under a Prince.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Can he be lesse, whom you will make happy
To boast in the possession of your faire
Person, a thousand provinces, those eyes
Are able to create another Indies;
All the delights that dwell in blessed Tempe
Divinely bud and blossome in your cheeke,
The treasure of Arabia'sin your breath,
Nor Thebes alone, as to Amphions Lute
Stoopes to the heavenly magicke of your voyce,
But all the world.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: No more of this, these praises
Are made for children, and will make truth blush,
They may fill up where nature is defective,
And were I Queene of Naples I should punish
Such flattery, but you are young and may
Outgrow this vanity.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: You are mercifull.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: I shall be ever so to you Octavio,
Let this incourage you to thinke I love you
In the first place, of those which are borne subjects,
If you will answer my respects forbeare
To question further.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: I shall waite sometime, and kisse your hand.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: And if my power may
Prevaile to doe you favour with the King,
Make your addresse.

sp.speaker: Octavio
sp.l: Has not the court transform'd her.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Me thinkes I move upon a state already
And yet tis not the glory of his title
Affects my hope so much, his person's lovely,
And both together make the charme, I doe
Expect his royall presence, how shall I

Behave my lookes i.e. fashion, manage them. This sense of the word, though now obsolete, was sufficiently familiar in our poet’s days. It is found in Spenser and Shakespeare; and Cole, as Mr. Malone observes, in his Dictionary, 1679, “renders behave by tracto,” which he subsequently interprets, to govern, or manage. when he declares himselfe.

sp.speaker: Iacamo
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Domitilla
sp.l: Admit not every Lord to trouble me,
